It all comes back to the actual matches - I found that changing tactics to almost anything else works for about 3 matches, then quickly falls apart. This is in EPL, J League, la liga. Developing my own tactics with my players or downloading a "top" tactic, it doesn't matter.

Loads of games with 15/8 shots/on target vs 1/1 and losing 0-1. This should be the freak, not the regular. It seems to be punishing the player for playing the game. All the player ratings are basically tied to goals and winning the game, so when you lose despite dominating (key passes, key tackles, etc.) your players score low, their avg. goes down as does their value, not to mention your league position, and it all spirals.

It feels like nothing you do in the game really matters; everything is either extremely RNG or it's scripted, but the game engine is a blackbox and you have no idea what is making these decisions. Do shouts matter? Are my tactics good or is this luck? There isn't a "combat log" that can show you how each dice roll was determined with various + and - based on your players stats, you are trusting the game to be a reasonable actor despite the evidence to the contrary. You can't work out what works and what doesn't, especially when you can reload a game and get a completely different result.

Outside of the match engine, the game is too much and too little information at the same time. I'm inundated with useless scouting reports, but I have no idea how my avatars national team is doing unless I actively subscribe to it. Players playing for their countries? No idea. An under 18 *exists* at the club? Here is a detailed report. Champions League results? No thank you. It's like being trapped in a room with an Alexa who is subscribed to every detail of your club, but all you really want is to watch the sports news channel.

The game has a lot to live up to, obviously, compared to real world media coverage. But it doesn't create any kind of world with excitement or intrigue. There isn't a Sky Super Sunday type coverage option where you could see the highlights, hear the pundits, see how these teams form has been. It all gets lost in this information overload, every inbox item is just presented with equal shitty value.

After so many hours on this series, I'd love for this game to be a chillout, have something on tv in the background kind of game. Or an intense, high focus, detailed tactical game. But it's neither, it's just boring and frustrating.

As someone who has experienced numerous football management simulators over the years, I can confidently say that Football Manager 2024 is in a league of its own. This year's edition has truly set a new benchmark for what a sports management game can be.

First and foremost, the level of detail in FM 2024 is unparalleled. The depth of the database, with its accurate and comprehensive player stats, makes for an incredibly immersive experience. It feels like every decision I make, whether it's about player training, match tactics, or transfers, has a tangible impact on my team's performance and progression.

The tactical aspect of the game is another area where FM 2024 shines. The flexibility and depth offered in setting up tactics allow for a variety of playstyles. Whether you prefer a possession-based game or a more direct approach, the game equips you with all the tools you need to implement your vision. The match engine, with its refined graphics and realistic physics, brings these tactics to life in a way that's both visually appealing and strategically satisfying.

What also stands out in FM 2024 is the improved AI. Opponents and player agents behave in more realistic and unpredictable ways, adding to the challenge and excitement of the game. Negotiating contracts and dealing with player dynamics feels more lifelike, demanding a more strategic approach to management.

The user interface in this edition is the most user-friendly and intuitive yet. Navigating through the various aspects of the game is seamless, making it accessible for newcomers while still offering the depth that veterans of the series love.

In conclusion, Football Manager 2024 is not just a game; it's an exhaustive and exhilarating journey into the world of football management. The developers have outdone themselves, delivering a game that appeals to both the tactically minded and those looking for an in-depth simulation experience. If you're a fan of football, management, or just great games in general, FM 2024 is an absolute must-play. It's more than just a game; it's the closest thing to being in the dugout.

It's a bit of a mix:

The match engine is the best it's been in a long time. You can make all kinds of interesting tactics work well, it's not a case of having to play in a specific way. With one exception - the pressing, I'll explain that below.

The core issue is that fatigue has a pretty low impact in order to have fewer injuries and generally be less of a problem than it should, because players always complain about injuries. If you try it, you'll see you don't even need to rotate that much, long injuries are rare and you can play pressing all season by just giving players rest days from training. The side effect is that even crappy AI teams can afford to play a hard press all season with relatively little drawback, and of course pressing hard makes them more effective than they should be able to. Other than buffing bad teams, this also leads to a climate of mayhem in the games because everyone is running around like crazy, and you get some wacky results and leagues.

One more issue is that morale is more overblown than usual. Goes for you and the AI. You can ride a morale wave to a season of invincibility, or you can have a rough patch just because a couple of guys complained about playing time, and your rival then rides the morale wave to a season of invincibility. Morale matters but in this version it's oversensitive.

One last thing I like is that in the match engine you can now make use of players who aren't fast or big, they aren't as useless as in the past. You can even play old players who are intelligent but slow and they can still do things even at a high level team.

Here is a (very long) review from a player who is:
[list]
[*] Loves playing sim and tycoon games
[*] Coming from FM22, and played FM20.
[*] Plays only on Indonesian league, where most players attributes at its peak is below decent compared to european standards.
[*] Playing create-a-club mode
[*] Uses a custom DB (5 level Indonesian Pyramid and much more leagues) with :
[list]
[*] Starting point at Indonesian 5th division
[*] 200k+ players
[*] 50+ leagues active (at least top3 nations from each continent is playable for the top 2 level, 80% of available asian nation is top 2 level playable and below that is view only)
[/list]
[*] With PC specs as follows:
[list]
[*] R9 5950X, 32GB @ 3200Mhz, RX 6800XT
[/list]
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*]3D match engine for Players is an absolute banger. Improved significantly compared to FM22. 
[list]
[*]Player animation is smooth, way more realistic (their body actually lean, twists etc depending on their required movement), and expressive (had a CB showing his anger by throwing his hands towards my GK that made a stupid pass and regretfully hold his hands behind his head). 
[*]GK actually do saves by every single part of their body. 
[*]Tackles and shooting movement is much better, players getting tackled is (most of the time) no longer like a bugged pedestrian animation in vanilla GTA San Andreas. 
[*]Ridiculous rubberbanding (when defender with significant pace-related attributes advantages or attackers with "winds up opponents trait") like a Need for Speed's cops is no longer happening. 
[*]RUNNING IS NO LONGER DRUNK, in FM22 my players (in vertical scroll cam) almost all the time NEVER RUN STRAIGHT, in this edition however, their run is actually straight enough to be called as sober.
[/list]
    [*]3D match engine for THE BALL is an amazing improvement compared to FM22. 
[list]
[*]The ball now has A REALISTIC TRAJECTORY where its movement is based on the last contact. No more ball turning and moving along with the player without making any contact. 
[*]Swerving ball is now much more realistic, its spinning speed is equivalent to how much swerve the player put into the ball.
[/list]
    [*]Simulation engine is way faster and responsive. My FM22 save has 160k players enabled and I would confidently say this edition is ~35% faster despite having much more players included, but take this as a grain of salt, it could also be the custom db that makes this point, but overall, the speed improvement is noticeable and much more enjoyable playing my FM24 save than the FM22.
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
[*]Realism outside the squad, staff, tactics, and match management is lacking because there is no physical evidence of the facilities other than our home stadium. For example, a club has a very small capacity stadium with terrible condition field, but its training and youth facilities is superb, corporate facilities graded as top, junior and youth recruitment is exceptional, it just don't make any sense because mostly we can't see the physical evidence of this facilities. Making my club has its own training and/or youth complex different with its stadium (like Real Madrid, including after several long saves in FM20) so far is not possible.
[*]The 3D match cameras is basically stagnant for the last few years. Director camera has the MOST VARIETY OF ANGLES, but the chance of it chooses angles other than the default TV-like camera is insulting. If this camera was meant to be "PoV of your club's director/president" then it should not have multi-angle views during highlights. If this is actually a 'directed camera', then make it like the way most in-game esports titles has its own automated action-directed camera. I also don't understand why there is no "Player PoV" camera, or better yet we can control the movement of our character during the match if using 3D view. It would add so much flavor and realism inside the game. I sincerely hope FM in their new engine for future titles have this.
    [*]The game's managerial aspect is getting deeper and more accurate to its counterparts (for example, the set piece coach, set piece routines, and squad planning feature, which is good), but it is mostly graph and text. We are a text and data, not a character. We don't know how our clubs complex looks like, we can't even roam our club's stadium in our free days and/or during/after the match, interaction with players titled "put hands on his shoulders" but no animation or anything. For me, sometimes this creates a certain level of boredom. I want to see my clubs whole facilities in person you know? Since I've worked hard for most of that.
[*]Going from amateur to pros gives me some stupid contract issues (or if it just GM features that still stupid). Two legitimately funny (and frustrating) case is 
[list]
 [*] one of my player is on youth contract, I instruct my GM to extend its contract, it was fine, but when the actual contract trigger date happens, the news shows the player as "going professional", with "N/A" contract values, and his status is actually a free agent, what the hell?
 [*] all of my staffs is in amateur contract except my technical director, I instruct TD to update all my contract staff just to find that 60% of my staff never wanting to make it full contract, while the other 40% getting a new full-time contract, with N/A salary for a few years, which when I checked by "change contract offer", the salary values is actually 0. What is this? Modern slavery?
[/list]
[/list]

The game was not refined, and still feels behind FM23.2 in some ways. I recommend the in game editor for some occasional bugs, or at least don't force disable it in your save.

Negatives:
- The AI still doesn't rotate well so you can run into very tired teams somewhat early in the season.

Pros:

- Injuries bring a challenge without feeling game breaking (lol at Tottenham IRL). Forces me to use players and formations I might otherwise not for a few games here and there.

Sadly, I can not recommend this game.
Sure it works and is fun to play, but I'm starting to see a trend, the same trend FIFA started showing all those years ago.

For example; The Squadplanner is completely useless and they show no effort to even fix it.
"But I can use it? I haven't noticed any issues with it?"

If you haven't noticed issues with it, it is because you are not rigorously using shortlists.
Whenever you have really huge shortlists the performance of the Squadplanner gets ruined for whatever reason. When you open the Squadplanner, the game slows down to a crawl and in worst case scenarios, the game can even crash if the shortlists are big enough; I've witnessed it myself.

This is a bug that has been present since FM23 Beta. Worst part? It was reported on their bug forum way back then and I did my own post in FM24 Beta. But it hasn't been fixed, it's still in the game.

Even though they say on the forum that they will look into it, they don't. Hence, the same bad feeling that FIFA started to give me years ago, where it is all about fixing superficial issues, issues that the broadest range of players will encounter.

It's the equivalent of a car, they fix the frame so it looks all nice and neat but under the hood there are glaring issues in the engine department that they don't seem to care about fixing, because most players might not even open the hood. Which is why you see constant fixes to the match engine, because all players are exposed to it.

I don't know, I think it's a really bad path to be on for this franchise.
Despite how many bug reports we do, it doesn't seem to matter unless it is a widely experienced issue or superficial at first glance.

There are other issues with the Squadplanner as well, such as that it auto populates, absolutely ruining any usage it might have, since it is used to create plans, but if those plans are constantly altered, then what is the point?

They also pushed into it some really important stuff such as the Comparison screen that is important as well as Assistant Reports etc. But forget about using these if you prefer to use shortlists for scouting purposes and to target players for your club. The bigger your shortlists, the less performance all these things get, since they're all under the Squadplanner main category.


The game is playable yes, but for how long? Some features aren't working and it looks grim in the future due to negligence. Squadplanner was one of the flagship features of FM23 and it hasn't been fixed since the FM23 Beta.

It smells a lot like FIFA and I don't like it.
They need to change course and start caring more about the quality of their product, not how many sales they'll get, otherwise history will repeat itself..

Football Manager 2024 is the latest installment in the long-running management simulation series, and it's another solid entry that will please fans of the genre. This year, Sports Interactive has focused on making the game more accessible to new players, while also adding in a number of new features and improvements for experienced players. 

One of the biggest changes in this years iteration is the new transfer system. It's now much easier to find and sign players, and you have more control over the negotiations. You can also now set specific targets for your scouts, which will help them find players who fit your style of play.

Another new addition is the ability to create your own set pieces. You can now design your own corner kicks, free kicks, and throw-ins, which you can then save and share with other players.


Overall, FM24 is a game that will appeal to both new and experienced players. It's packed with new features and improvements, and it's one of the most addictive and engrossing management sims ever made.

Here are some of the pros and cons of Football Manager 2024:

Pros:

More accessible to new players
New transfer system
Ability to create your own set pieces
Improved match engine
More exciting matches
Cons:

Can be overwhelming for new players
Some of the new features are a bit buggy

If you're a fan of management sims, then you should definitely check out FM24. It's a game that will keep you entertained for hours on end.

Another year, another FM. 

Sadly, just like last year, Sports Interactive marketed well only to under deliver on their much promised 'most polished version ever'. Currently the game is a mess. AI squad building (key feature this year) is terrible; players are still being bought and not played, youth teams become empty, squad rotation doesn't happen. 

Player Interactions (another key feature) are just as wild. 

Match Engine (another key feature) is wonderful in attack, yet defensively is a nightmare. 

And the Japanese A-League (super feature) license is... half-baked. 

Sadly, Sports Interactive and SEGA are the defacto football manager game at the moment, so they can get away with these terrible releases. Its a shame really, as the ME (defending aside) looks great this year and the processing speed is lightning fast, even with a huge database. 

I just wish someone would muzzle and reign in Miles Jacobson from over promising every damn year, and let the team fix legacy bugs before adding new half-finished/forgotten features that cause new issues. 

As it currently stands I do not recommend this game, hopefully one of the two allotted patch windows Pre/Post-Winter Update will fix the majority of them. Hopefully.

Let's see ... where to begin ... 

Licensing issues. A mess. The much hyped Japanese "fully licensed" leagues are - guess what? Not fully licensed and so players who want to experience them are out of luck until SI gets its act together.

AI squad building. A mess. AI still signs multi-million pound players for obscene fees and with no logic whatsoever to the deals ... and then doesn't play them.

MOST TEAMS DO NOT MAKE SUBSTITUTIONS ... yes, you've read that correctly. Almost all substitutions in the game come as a result of injuries or fatigue and happen from 85 minutes onward. Spot the tactical substitution and win a star prize. And this is WORSE in the academy section of the game where entire weeks go by without the AI subbing ANY players at all which destroys the late game.

The Champions League new format, which worked fine in 2023 version, draws clubs from the same countries against each other ... what a joke. No-one in-house at SI spotted that before release? 

I could go on and on. The game has been out for a fortnight in Early Access. You HOPE that some of these issues will be resolved on Day One ... instead, nothing. And some vague promises about a patch somewhere along the line, which probably means weeks. 

There is NO WAY I can justify recommending this title. And I have often added a caveat to that sort of statement "at the moment." But this is a joke. So I'm not changing this review later on. The release version is unacceptable. It's dire. And a lot of people feel conned by the Japanese licensing thing.

This is the first FM game in about ten years that I have felt able to give a positive review to, and that is purely because of one feature that has been requested for years going back to the days of Domark's Championship Manager on the Amiga. That feature is the ability to import your save(s) from the previous version; that feature alone makes this version worth buying for anyone with significant hours invested in a save from FM23.

Getting a new database update each version/year is fine, until you've played a few seasons in your save, as it will have diverged so far from reality that it doesn't matter whether you started with 'real' players or a completely random database of players. Ten seasons in, and most clubs are unrecognisable from the ones that started the game. The enjoyment for most long term players is taking a small team/club and transforming them over a number of seasons, often twenty or more, and watching the rise and fall of players you've brought in and nurtured into superstars. You can now carry on that save from year to year without having to start from scratch each time.

The rest of the game is basically the same old story. Tiny improvements, some screens moved around, a couple of changes to the UI here and there, and an up to date database of players and staff. The match engine has got a bigger facelift than normal, and is a lot more fluid and 'feels' realistic for once, however, it still looks like it was made in 2002 using assets from Kevin Thom's Football Manager on the spectrum - but I suppose small steps and all that.

Price-wise, again, it's at least twice as expensive as it should be for what you are getting in terms of upgrades. Owners of previous versions should be getting a hefty discount of around 50% for this as it simply isn't worth the money over previous versions. If you do not own any other versions then ¬£40 is reasonable, although ¬£30 would be fair.

As I said in last years review, we have zero choice, the game has no realistic competition so if you want to play football manager then you get this whether you like it or not.

And the in-game editor is now ¬£6.99, for something which should be included for free. You can buy fan made editors for less than that with more features, although slightly less convenient. People who bought this in early access should get this for free regardless.

Probably, it's the best FM release in years. The new set piece creator is a game changer. Now, you don't need to manage set pieces before every match and with every substitute (or leave them as is with a loss of efficiency). Still, it's disappointing that the limit is only three routines per type; that number is clearly not enough for corners.
Woodwork is (partially) fixed, yay! Now you can score (a lot) of goals off the frame. Better than nothing. Too bad it took almost 20 years to do that.
Also, SI gets bonus points for licensing J-League and the possibility to import saves from FM23.
There are some quirks with the match engine, for example, too many critical errors by goalkeepers, but it's nothing unusual for an early release. Everything should be stable around 24.3 or 24.4.
So, to summarize. Don't miss the last classic (non-Unity) FM. Honestly, I planned to skip FM24, but set pieces, J-League, and support for old saves convinced me otherwise.
